perturbation.original_text: Report to the other Party, in writing, any use and/or disclosure of the Confidential Information that is not permitted or required by this Agreement of which a Party becomes aware within five (5) days of a Party=s discovery of such unauthorized use and/or disclosure
perturbation.changed_text: Report to the other Party, in writing, any use and/or disclosure of the Confidential Information that is not permitted or required by this Agreement of which a Party becomes aware within ninety (90) days of a Party=s discovery of such unauthorized use and/or disclosure
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires reporting of unauthorized disclosures within five days. HIPAA regulations require covered entities and business associates to have policies and procedures to detect and report breaches of protected health information (PHI). While HIPAA does not mandate a specific timeframe for internal reporting, a 5-day window may be considered insufficient for identifying, investigating, and reporting complex breaches, potentially leading to non-compliance if investigations are rushed or incomplete. Extending the reporting period to 90 days creates a conflict with the expectation of timely breach reporting and mitigation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
